definitions.definition: When many health plans or programs are combined into one plan that can cover someone for the whole day.
Remove or cover a dangerous material, such as lead or mercury, from water, paint, or air, or other places.
Your belly or tummy area.
To able to or can do.
To remove or destroy a body part or tissue. This can be done in many ways, including surgery, radiation, or drugs.
Something that is not usual, like a growth or low or high amounts of blood cells.
To end or get rid of.
A scrape or scratch.
Caused by an infection; a pocket of pus. You can get them anywhere in your body.
When you miss work or school.
To take in or soak up fluids.
To not do or not use.
To hurry up or make worse.
To be able to get into something or place.
Buildings, facilities, and technology are usable by all persons.
Something that is available or can be understood easily.
To adjust to or adapt to something.
To take with or go along with.
To do or carry out something.
So or for that reason.
Groups of doctors or hospitals that work together to make quality of care better.
When an organization is reviewed by a professional organization to make sure it meets certain rules.
To add or build up.
To gather up or collect.
The use of pressure or massage at specific points on the body to control symptoms such as pain or nausea.
The use of thin needles through the skin at specific points on the body to control pain and other symptoms.
A person trained to do accupuncture or accupressure.
Something that is true or right.

This kind of drug is used to lower your blood pressure. They make your heart work less hard. It is used to treat heart disease and to keep heart failure from getting worse. If your blood pressure is lower that also helps lower your chance of stroke or heart attack. These drugs are also used to treat diabetes and kidney problems. There are many different names for these drugs, including lisinopril, benazepril, and quinapril. Also called angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors.
a vaccine that only contains part of the virus
An over-the-counter (OTC) drug that relieves many types of pain. A brand name for this drug is Tylenol.
Connects muscles in the back of the lower leg to the back part of the foot.
Occurs when your stomach contents come back up into your esophagus, causing heartburn, also called acid reflux. A longer lasting form is called gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
A skin condition when the space where hairs grow get clogged up with oil and dead skin cells.
To get.
A disease caused by a virus (HIV or human immunodeficiency virus) that makes it hard for your body to fight diseases. Also called AIDS.
To begin or turn on.
Being able to fight off a disease once you have had that disease. Also called adaptive immunity.
An illness or symptom that begins suddenly or lasts a short time. It can also be an intense flare-up of an illness.

A fast-growing disease that occurs when there are too many of of a specific type of white blood cells (called lymphocytes or lymphoblasts). A fast-growing disease. Also called acute lymphoblastic leukemia or ALL. It is the most common type of cancer in children.

A fast-growing disease that occurs when there are too many of a type of white blood cell (myeloblast) that crowds out other types of blood cells. It is the most common type of leukemia in adults. Also called AML.
Being able to fight off a disease once you have had that disease. Also called active immunity.
A person who cannot stop using substances, such as medications or alcohol.
Something that, if you take it often, will be hard to stop taking.
Extra or added.
To talk about or discuss.
Enough or the right amount.
To stick to or follow treatment.
Next to or near.
Something that is added to a vaccine to make it work better.
To give to (a person) or to take care of a project.
The day that the hospital started treating the patient.
Controls your sex drive and stress.
When your provider lets you know before a certain treatment that they think that Medicare won't pay for it.
Something that is helpful or useful.
Harmful, such as a bad reaction to a medication.
Something bad that happens that you did not expect.
To tell or suggest.
To support, fight on behalf of someone or something.
requies or needs oxygen to live
Slow and steady exercises, like walking, running, biking, swimming, that help your heart stay healthy and work better
A spray or mist
Tagree to a request.
A law that increases health insurance for people who are not insured and expands Medicaid.
Neither male or female; genderless.
In illness, to make worse or harm. In emotions, anger or hurt.
To put together or combine.
When the whole family must pay costs for medical bills before the insurance company covers any of the cost. Also called "out-of-pocket" costs. See also "embedded deductible."
In diseases: fast growing or dangerous In emotions: pushy
To be anxious or restless.
Sickness or illness.
The tubes that take air in and out of your lungs.
definitions.altText: The tubes (trachea and bronchi) going from the mouth tother lungs. The tubes are colored light blue; the lungs are colored purple.

definitions.definition: Occurs when fat builds up in your liver when you drink a lot of alcohol. this causes damage to your liver and it does not work as well as it should. Also called alcoholic fatty liver disease.
Something, like pollen, dust, mold, or animal dander, that causes a reaction in your body, such as a rash or sneezing.
Caused by your body's reaction in your nose to mold, pollen, or dust. Also called hay fever.
Your body's reaction (sneezing, rash, coughing) to something, like pollen or dust. Reactions can be serious or minor.
A doctor who treats people with reactions to things such as pollen, dust, or mold (allergies).
To ease, lessen a symptom.
To divide or distribute.

Healthy stem cells (blood-forming cells) are given to a patient to replace their own stem cells that have been destroyed by treatment. The new cells come from a person whose genes are similar to those of the patient. Also called a stem cell transplant.
To let, to give permision for.
Hair loss due to family history, disease, or medication.

This kind of drug is used with other drugs to treat high blood pressure. It can also be used to treat prostate problems in men. There are many different names for these drugs, including nebivolol and tamsulosin.
A type of drug to treat high blood pressure. They lower your heart rate and relax the blood flow. There are different names for these drugs, including clonidine and tizanidine.
To change, shift, or adjust.
To take turns.
A choice or option.
The tiny air sacs in the lungs.
The silver-colored fillings, mixture of metals used to fill cavities in teeth.
To put together or join.
When one of your eyes doesn't work properly with your brain. Also called lazy eye.
To walk or move around.
To able to walk or move around.
When medical care can be given outside of the hospital, without a person being admitted (outpatient care).
To improve or make better.
To change or adjust.
When you are not able to remember new information.
A way to check on a baby's health before it is born, using a small amount of fluid from around the baby.
The fluid surrounding unborn baby in a mother's womb.
A disease that attacks the nerve cells in your brain and spinal cord that carry messages to your muscles. Also called ALS, Lou Gehrig's Disease, or motor neuron disease.
Something that does not need oxygen to live. The opposite of aerobic.
Fast exercise, such as sprinting, or muscle-building exercise, like weight lifting.
A pain reliever, over-the counter (such as aspirin or acetominopen) or prescription drugs.
To study or examine.
A serious allergic reaction that happens quickly and can be fatal.
Things that help support treatment, like tests, imaging, or therapy.
Condition that blocks the body from using male hormones. Person with androgen insensitivity may have physical traits of a female but the genetics of a male.
A low red-blood count. Your blood does not have enough of the cells that carry oxygen (hemaglobin) to your body. Also called "tired blood"or "low iron".
A drug that reduces pain (a local anesthetic) or that puts you to sleep (a general anesthetic), as during surgery.
A substance that is used to reduce sensitivity to pain. See also "anesthesia."
A bulge in the wall of an artery. If it gets large, it can burst and cause serious bleeding.
Chest pain or disconfort that you feel when there is not enough blood flowing to your heart. Stable angina is also called "angina pectoris".

A limit that insurance companies set for how much they are willing to pay a patient in healthcare costs for the entire year a the patient is enrolled in that plan. This is no longer allowed under the law for long-term plans.
Something that occurs once a year.
Something that is different or unusual.
An eating disorder, where you eat much less than your needs.
The front of the body.
A band of tissue that is in the middle of the knee.
Your front teeth.
A drug to reduce swelling and so reduce pain.
A drug that fights a virus, like those that cause the flu. Also called anti-virus.
A drug bacterial infections.
Cells in your blood that fight infections or other abnormal substances.
To think ahead.

These types of drugs, also called blood thinners, help prevent blood clots from forming or getting bigger. Blood clots can cause blockages in arteries or veins, heart attacks or strokes. There are different names for these drugs, including warfarin and dabigatran.
a drug that treats an infection caused by a fungus
An abnormal substance in your body that must be fought off by antibodies.
Describes something that kills or slows things like bacteria, viruses, and fungi.
When you have high number of antibodies that are related to blood clots. Also known as APS.
A blood test to see if you are at risk for blood clots.

These types of drugs, also called blood thinners, prevent blood cells (platelets) from forming a clot. Blood clots can cause blockages in arteries or veins, heart attacks or strokes. There are different names for these drugs, including prasugrul and clopidogrel.
Worry or fear.
When the valve for your aorta doesn't open enough and blocks the flow of blood to your heart.
When it is difficult for you to to talk, read, or write.
Something that is clear, or when somoen show up.
The name of the person who is filling out a form, such as for a job or for insurance.
For medicine: To put or rub on. For a form or rule: To use the right form or follow the right rule.
In medicine: to find. Also to thank or be grateful.
To inform or tell.
A good fit or the right way to use something.
About or around.
An ability, skill, or talent.
Something that is watery.

This kind of drug is used to lower your blood pressure. It is used to treat heart disease because it lets your heart work less hard. There are many different names for these drugs, including losartan, valsarten, and olmesartan. Also called angiotensin II receptor beta blockers.
Something that is possible.
A problem with the rate of your heart or when your heart doesn’t have a steady beat.
When a heartbeat is irregular, or the rate or rhythm of the heart is too fast or too slow.
Happens when the walls of the arteries get narrow and hard. Also called hardening of the arteries.
Vessels that carry blood from the heart to the body's organs.
Pain in your joints.
A disease of the joints that causes swelling, pain, heat, and stiffness.
To say or tell.
To find out or or make certain.
Vitamin C.
To choke or suffocate.
A way to take out fluid or tissue for a test or to breathe in food or other things into your lungs.
Another name for a lab test.
To review or evaluate, such as checking to see if a drug or exericse is helping or not. Also, a test to review.
To help.
To link two or more things together.
A group or organization.
A long-term (or chronic) disease that affects the airways to your lungs. When they are swollen, you can not breathe easily.
When you can't see clearly close up or far away.
A person who is sick, but does not feel or look sick. If lots of people are sick but don't feel sick, they can help spread a disease (also known as asymptomatic transmission).
A loss of muscle movement.
A disease where your arteries get stiff and clogged by things in your blood, such as fat and calcium, called "plaque".
A long- lasting itchy red rash, caused by a skin reaction.
The sudden start of a disease.
To meet a goal.
To try.
A type of vaccine that uses a weakened form of the virus.
Your clothing.
To review or look at.
Related to your sense of hearing.
Something that is original or true.
A trusted source or person.
To allow or give the power to someone.
Affects how a person talks to and interacts with other people and how they learn. Also called autism, Asperger's syndrome or ASD.
A disease that makes your body attack healthy cells by mistake.
Someone who is independent, can act on their own.
On hand or nearby.
A disease that chickens and other birds get. People who work closely with birds can sometimes catch it too. Also called bird flu or HPAI.
Do not do.
Your armpit.
Very small living things, or “bugs,” that can be helpful (they help to digest food) or can cause illness (strep throat, for example).
This happens when a healthcare provider is not in the network of a patient's healthcare insurance. They will bill the patient any costs that is not covered by insurance.
When you act in an angry way or have trouble paying attention or sitting still.
Something that is helpful or good.
Someone you pick to receive benefits if you die.
Has a good effect or provides an advantage.
Something that isn't harmful or is not cancer.
A prostate gland that has gotten bigger. A normal part of aging in men. It is not cancer. Also called enlarged prostate gland.
The grief you feel after a death, sadness, mourning.

This kind of drug slows how fast your heart is beating. It also lowers thow strongly your heart muscle contracts for a short time. When you use it for more time, a beta blocker helps to keep your heart failure from becoming worse. It may also help strengthen your heart. There are many different names for these drugs, including atenolol, metoprolol, and nebivolol.
Something that you drink, fluids, liquids.
Something that occurs two times a year.
Something that happens every other year, every two years.
On both sides.
A sticky film with germs found on your teeth. Also called plaque.
A living thing that can cause something to happen, such as a virus or bacteria.
When a piece of tissue from a part of your body is taken for testing.
Plants and animals.
To spread fear or harm using a virus or bacteria.
Designed to prevent pregnancy. Also called contraception. There are different methods, inlcuding pills, devices implanted in our body, or surgery for women or men (sterilization).

A problem that happens while a baby is developing in the mother's body, often very early in pregnancy. Birth defects affect how the body looks and works. They include heart disease, cleft lip, and Fragile X Syndrome.
A hollow organ that stores pee (urine).
A fluid in your body that carries things that are needed for your body to work well, such as vitamins, minerals, and oxygen to cells. It also takes waste products away.

Blood clots occur naturally when you are cut to stop the bleeding. They disappear when your body heals. But sometimes, blood clots do not dissolve or there are too many of them, and they can travel to distant body parts, such as your brain or heart.
The main types of blood sugar in your body.
A test to find how much lead is in your body.
The force of your blood pressing against the walls of your arteries. The high number (systolic pressure) measures when your heart beats and the low number (diastolic pressure) measures between beats.
A blood test that shows each type of blood cell. Also called a complete blood count or CBC.
A small amount of blood taken from the finger or arm to be tested.
The main sugar in the blood that comes from food and is the main source of energy for the body,
Tiny tubes that move blood around the body. Includes three main types (arteries, veins, capillaries).
A way to measure your body fat based on your height and weight. Also called BMI.
How strong your bones are.
A test of how solid and how strong your bones are. A test for brittle bones (osteoporosis).
The tissue inside some of your larger bones where blood cells are made.
When a small sample of bone marrow is removed from a bone. The liquid is sent to a laboratory to be studied.
When a small sample of bone is removed and sent to a laboratory to be studied.
The solid tissues that help you to move and support your body. They grow and change during your life.
A shot that you get months or years after your first vaccine shot, to help keep you safe from certain diseases.
The last step of food moving through your body. Also called poop, stool, or feces.
A swelling of the nerves in your arms.
When your heart beats slowly.
The organ that controls your thoughts, memory, speech, and movements. It also controls the functions of many organs.
definitions.altText: Side view of the brain with each lobes in a different color.

definitions.definition: Getting ill even though you've been protected against the disease.
Feeding a baby with milk from the breast; nursing.
A baby that is born feet or rear-end first.
The tubes that take air in and out of your lungs.
A drug that helps you breathe easier.
When you clench or grind your teeth.
The side of your mouth.
The results, effects, or costs of a plan or disease.
Joint pain caused by swelling in a tiny sac between your bones and muscles, tendons, or skin.
Butt, backside, rear end.
Using or with.
When.
A mineral that makes your bones and teeth strong.

This kind of drug lowers your blood pressure. It can also be used to treat chest pain and a heart beat that is not regular. There are many different names for these drugs, including amlodipine, diltiazem, and nifedipine.
To add up or figure out.
A hard crusty coating on teeth or a "stone" in an organ (kidney or bladder stones, for example).
The back part of the lower leg.
The top of the skull bone. Also called skull cap.

Occurs when new cells grow rapidly, even when they are not needed. These cells crowd out other cells. Cancer can occur anyplace in your body. There are many types of cancer, including those that begin in your blood (leukemia), in specific organs (kidney cancer) or tissues (soft tissue sarcoma).
Sharp teeth, right next to your incisors. Also called eye teeth or cuspids.
Small, round sores in your mouth.
To be able to do something or capable of doing something.
The size of an object. Can also mean ability.
Tiny blood vessels that connect the small arteries and veins.
A small amount of blood that is taken from your finger to run a simple test. Also called a "finger stick."
Something that causes cancer.
A type of cancer that begins in your skin or the lining of an organ.
Related to your heart.
A doctor who treats heart and blood vessel problems.
The study of heart and blood vessel problems, or the medical department that treats heart and blood vessel problems.
Having to do with your heart and blood vessels.
Holes in your teeth. Also called cavities or tooth decay.
When the arteries in your neck become narrow or blocked.
Injury to a nerve in your wrist that happens when you do the same motion over and over again.
The bones in the wrist that connect to the bones in the middle of the hand.
A person who is sick and can get other people sick.
The smooth covering on the end of your bones.
The number that tells how many people die from a disease ina certain group of people, such as a city or state.
Someone who helps people who are sick to get the help they need.
Details of one patient’s illness, including symptoms, diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up.
A type of study that compares people who have an illness or other health condition (cases) to a group of people without that condition (controls).
A special type of imaging that creates three-dimensional X-rays. Also called CT scans or computed axial tomography.
A clouding of the eye that makes it hard to see, often in older people.
A disaster or tragedy.
A type or group.
A tube for putting fluids into or taking them out of your body.
To put a tube into a part of your body.
Towards the bottom of the body, away from the head.
Something that leads your body to react.
To burn your skin to stop bleeding.
A warning or detail to think about.
To stop or quit.
A disease where you cannot eat foods with gluten, found in many grains, such as wheat. If youeat gluten it wll damage your small intestine.
To take cells or tissues from your body and watch them grow.
An infection of your skin and the cells underneath.
A hard covering of the outside of the root of your tooth below the gum line.
To blame or punish.

definitions.term: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
definitions.definition: The agency that studies health, safety, and security. Also called the CDC.
Includes the brain and spinal cord. Also called CNS.

A stroke, bleeding that occurs in your brain. Also called cerebral accident or cerebrovascular accident or CVA. An ischemic stroke, caused by a blood clot that blocks a blood vessel in the brain. A hemorrhagic stroke is caused by a blood vessel that breaks and bleeds into the brain.
A stroke or cerebral hemorrhage.
Earwax.
The lower part of the womb, where the baby grows during pregnancy.
When a baby is born through surgery. Also called a C-section.
To stop or quit.
A trait or feature.
To tell about or describe.
A treatment that removes lead from your body if your blood lead levels are very high.
A drug that kills cancer cells.
An X-ray, or picture, of your chest.
Paint from your house that is coming off in pieces.
Caused by a germ (a bacteria) that is passed during oral or genital sex from one person to another.
A kind of fat in your blood. Some cholesterol is useful in your body. Too much can lead to diseases such as hardening of your arteries (atherosclerosis) or coronary artery disease.
Something, like a disease or symptom, that lasts for a long time.
A serious, long-term illness that affects many body systems. It is also called myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS).
Damaged kidneys can't filter blood the way that they should. Wastes can build up in your body, in addition to other health problems.
Occurs when there are too many of of a type of white blood cell (lymphocytes) that crowd out other types of blood cells. Chronic leukemias grow slowly. Also called CLL.
Occurs when there are too many of a type of white blood cell (granulocytes) that crowd out other types of blood cells. Chronic leukemias grow slowly. Also called CML.
Lung diseases, such as chronic bronchitis or emphysema. Also called COPD.
When you're unable to go to sleep or wake up at the right times.
The flow of blood through the body.
The removal of the foreskin of the penis in surgery.
Scarring of the liver because of injury or long-term disease. Scar tissue cannot perform the functions of liver tissue, so your liver function is not as good as it needs to be.
Person who identifies as the gender assigned to them at birth.
Your collarbone.
Happens when your baby's mouth or lip do not form properly. There can be an opening in their lip or one in the roof of their mouth (also called the palate) or both.
Research studies that test new treatments on patients.
Surgery that changes the appearance of a clitorus (female sex organ).
To help or work together.
When blood cells clot or clump together.
The last bone at the bottom of the spine. Also called tailbone.
To force.
Related to thinking.
To be aware of.
The percentage of a healthcare plan that is not covered by the insurance company. For example, a 30% coinsurance for a $100 bill means that you would pay $30 yourself.
Sex.
A fussy or crying baby.
To work together or help each other.
Part of the large intestine.
Looks at the inside of the large intestine using a flexible tube with a ltiny camera at the end.
Concerning the colon and the rectum. The large intestine.
When a person is deeply unconcious because of illness or injury. A person in a coma cannot move or talk.
To be in a coma.
A vaccine that helps stop more than one type of disease, such as the TDaP (tetanus, diphtheira, and pertussis).
To mix 2 or more things; or a mixture.
To start or begin.
A promise.
Something that happens often.
An illness that can be spread to other people. Also called "catching".
To talk or write to others or to let you know.
When a group is protected from a disease. Also called herd immunity.
When a disease spreads and there is no close link to another confirmed case of the disease.
Something, such as a drug, that is similar to another drug.
To pay or make up for something bad that has happened.
Someone who is skillful or well trained.
Your illness or symptom that is most important; the main reason you go to the doctor. Also known as "chief complaint".
To finish or fill out.
Something that is free or given away.
Following a medical plan or doctor’s instructions. Also, following the law.
A part or a section of a larger object.
A tooth-colored filling, not a silver-colored (or amalgam) filling.
Something that is complete or thorough.
To squeeze or press down on.
To include.
Weakened.
When you have a strong urge or desire to do something.
A special type of imaging that creates three-dimensional X-rays. Also called CT scans or CAT scans (computed axial tomography).
To hide or be hidden.
To become pregnant.
The amount of an ingredient in a drug or medicine.
Is about.
To end or finish.
Something that is definite or final,
To agree or feel the same way.
A head injury caused by a big impact or shaking.
A medical problem, like a disease or an illness.
Training or exercising your body.
To do something or to carry out a project.
A group of genetic conditions that limit hormone production in the adrenal glands (above the kindeys).
Something that you are born with, such as a heart problem or cleft palate.
When the nose area is filled up with fluid or mucus. The nose canfeel stuffy or it can be hard to breathe.
When your heart can't pump enough blood. Also called heart failure or CHF.
A vaccine in 2 parts that makes it more effective.
An infection around your eyes. Also called pinkeye.
Someone who carefully follows rules.
A result.
So, or as a result.
To think about.
Something that stays the same.
To join or put together.
Something that is easy to see or obvious.
To be made of.
To make or build.
To talk with or discuss.
To eat or drink or to use up.
To talk, call, or get in touch with.
A disease that can be spread from one person to another. When someone is sick and might make you sick, too.
Has or holds.
A poison, or harmful material.
To infect someone or make some place dirty.
To think about or consider.
One thing will happen if another also does.
To go on.
Birth control.
To make something smaller or to catch a disease.
Something that is not recommended or not allowed.
A dye that helps make tissues or organs more visible on an X-ray or CT scan.
To give or help.
To manage, or take care of.
A medical study that compares one treatment to another treatment.
A bruise.
To meet.
Something that is easy to use or nearby.
To change.
Movements that you can't control caused by unusual activity in your brain. Also called a fit or seizure.
The amount that you pay yourself (out-of-pocket) for a service when it is given.
A lung disease that makes breathing hard. Also known as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, emphysema, or chronic bronchitis.
Related to the blood vessels that bring blood to the heart.
When the blood vessels that bring blood and oxygen to the heart become narrow. Also called coronary heart disease or CAD.
When the blood vessels that bring blood and oxygen to the heart become narrow. Also called coronary atery disease or CAD.
A heart attack.
A group of germs (viruses) that cause a variety of diseases, including severe acute respiratory syndorme (SARS) and Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS).
A disease caused by a new germ (virus) that causes fever, cough and difficulty breathing. It was first noticed in late 2019 in Wuhan, China. Also called 2019 Novel Coronavirus or COVID-19
Two or more things that are linked or related to each other.
To similar to or be in agreement with.
To confirm or agree with.
A type of drug that is used to treat a variety of diseases and conditions. They reduce swelling and help your immune system. Also called corticosteroids or glucocorticoids.
How to cough or sneeze so that you do infect as many people.
The amount of risk that is protected and paid for by the insurance company.

A new disease caused by a new germ (a virus called SARS-CoV-2) that causes fever, cough and difficulty breathing. It was first noticed in late 2019 in Wuhan, China. Also called 2019 Novel Coronavirus or coronavirus disease. It seems to have begun in bats and then moved to humans who worked closely with wild animals.
The big bones that make up the hips, or where the upper body meets the legs.
A type of dandruff that babies get.
The bones that are part of the head.
When a baby dies suddenly, without reason. Also called SIDS or Sudden Infant Death Syndrome.
A standard of evidence.
A disease that lasts for a long time and causes isevere irritation in your digestive tract (bowels).
When your upper teeth are biting inside the lower teeth, not with them,
Swelling around your vocal cords that causes breathing difficulties.
A covering on a tooth. Can be made from different materials, including porcelain or gold.
Very important.
Takes many X-ray pictures to combine into a better image. Stands for "computerized tomography scan."
The ability of an individual to understand and respect values, attitudes, and beliefs that differ across cultures, and to consider and respond appropriately to these differences.
To heal or make better.
Now.
A full, round face, like a patient with high levels of the hormone cortisol.
Related to your skin.
Pus or other liquid under your skin.
An infection in your bladder, often causes pain when you pee.
A type of blood thinner. It helps prevent clots from forming or getting bigger. Blood clots can cause blockages in arteries or veins, heart attacks or strokes.
Small pieces of skin. Also called dandruff when there are a lot of flakes.
Flaking and itchiness of your skin.
Harmful or not safe.
Facts or numbers.
When you can't hear any sounds at all.
To make weaker.
To die or pass away.
The first teeth that grow in young children. There are 20 primary teeth. They fall out and are replaced by permanent teeth. Also called milk teeth or baby teeth.
A choice.
To rot or break down.
To clean an object or buidlding, or person to kill germs or other harmful things.
To lower or make smaller.
The amount of money that you have to pay, out of your own pocket, before the insurance company will make any payments.
To think or believe.
A blood clot that forms in a vein deep in your body.
A device that gives the heart an electrical shock to make it start beating normally again.
To not have enough.
A shortage or not enough.
Something that is not a normal shape or is oddly shaped.
When something gets worse.
When you lose too much fluid or water from your body.
Work done to remove or cover lead paint. Also called abatement.
To remove or take out.
The muscle in your upper arm.
Memory loss that gets worse over time. It also affects how well you can do everyday chores and focus. The most common kind is Alzheimer's disease.
To show.
A nerve disease.
Holes in your teeth. Also called cavities or tooth decay.

definitions.definition: A fake tooth that is put into your jaw bone.
The soft tissue (dental pulp) in your teeth.
A thin layer painted onto teeth to prevent tooth decay.
The main bone-like part of a tooth.
A doctor who treats diseases in your teeth and gums.
The study of teeth and gums.
Fake teeth made to replace your own teeth. They can replace all of your teeth or just a few. Also called false teeth.
When there is no oxygen.

OTC medications are acetaminophen (Tylenol) and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as aspirin, naproxen (Aleve), and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin). Growths on your skin caused by an infection with a virus (the humanpapilloma virus, or HPV).
A disease that you can get from a mosquito bite that can be very mild or very serious (if it affects your brain).
When you have difficulty breathing.
While or but.
When the soft tissue of the neck (muscles and ligaments) are stretched. Also called neck sprain or strain.
A disease that causes you to cough and does not stop. It is very easily spread to other people. Also called pertussis.
An disease that you get from your parents (inherited). Your body cannot get rid of extra copper.
The tube that goes from your mouth to your lungs. Also called trachea.
To leave or take back.
To hold back or keep from.
To take or bear.
To see or observe.
Insurance from an employer that may give money and medical care if someone is injured while working.
A picture of the inside of your body, using small amounts of radiation.
When your mouth feels dry for a long time. Also called dry mouth.
Caused by a germ (a fungus) that can grow quickly, causing you to feel ill, in many parts of your body. Some examples are thrush (in your throat) or vaginal yeast infections in women.
Caused by a germ (a virus) that live in mosquitoes. It affects many parts of your body. The yellow fever virus is only found in certain parts of Africa and South America.
A disease caused by a germ (a virus) that is spread by mosquitos.
A mineral that is needed in small amounts to help the cells of your body work well.
A common, informal word for pimples or acne.
The kind of diseases that people can get from animals, such as Lyme disease (from ticks) or rabies (from many animals, including cats and dogs).
